VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The facility submitted 2 corrective action plans (CPA) during this reporting period.
The first CAP was in response to the renewal inspection that took place last year.
This required the facility to develop a CAP for rules 4113 (Central Registry Checks),
4114 (Tuberculosis Screening), 4130 (Privacy and Confidentiality, and 4128 (Initial
Staff orientation and training). Regarding rule 4114 the facility retrained
administration staff on the need to follow policy and ensure staff have a copy of their
TB testing prior to hire. This issue was not found during this inspection. Regarding
rule 4113 the new process of the state checking for long standing employees helped
and the facility is now doing regular compliance checks on the personal files for this
issue which appears to be successful since this was not an issue during this
inspection. Regarding rule 4130 the facility provided a copy of the changed policy
that does not permit video recording of any type. This policy was shared with staff
and again no violation was found during this inspection. Regarding rule 4128 the staff
were all trained on the required documentation needs and need to complete this
documentation in a timely manner. Again, this issue was not found during this
inspection. The second CAP submitted involved a special investigation
2024SIC0001475 which had two identified action steps. The first action step involved
an updated policy and procedure for discharges and emergency discharges. All staff
were to be trained on the changes which involved staff remaining present if a youth
is taken to the hospital or other medical care and supervision of youth is not to end
until a documented transfer has been completed. This was verified during quarterly
unannounced visits and the facility was appropriate in their follow through. The
second action step involves the new discharge policy and procedure being added to
the monthly policy reviews and updates. Staff will also review the new
policy/procedure every 6-months at the team meeting. This was verified during
quarterly unannounced visits and the facility was appropriate in their follow through.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
3

Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator outlines the efforts made to bring the facility into
compliance involving the single special investigation 2024SIC0001475 that
occurred during this reporting period. The Chief Administrator also outlines the
efforts to bring the facility into compliance with the violations found during the
annual renewal licensing inspection for 2023. None of the violations found in that
inspection were discovered during this interim inspection suggesting the facility was
successful in their compliance efforts. The Chief Administrator documents the Key
performance indicators (KPI) involved securing quality licensed clinical staff and the
facility was able to accomplish this task. Training was provided for the new clinical
staff to ensure they were completing their tasks per licensing/contract
requirements. The Chief Administrator documented there was one unplanned
discharge during this reporting period when a youth chose to leave the facility and
live on his own. The youth was within a couple of months of 18-years-old and
wanted to start independent living without waiting. This was not identified as a
systemic trend, and the facility made numerous efforts to help the youth make the
choice to wait until the foster care worker could set up an appropriate process.
Regarding policy changes that still need to be improved, the Chief Administrator
documented the program statement has been changed to match what the state
contract is requiring.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed reported positive attitudes and receiving significant training to
enhance their ability to work and provide best practice to the youth in the program.
The staff understood the responsibility for supervision and believed administration
are supportive of their efforts. Staff have knowledge of the youth’s treatment plans
and their interventions when working with the youth.
Youth were interviewed with only one youth having partial verbal ability. The youth
reported doing well and being taken care of. The interactions with staff were very
appropriate and the youth’s needs were cared for.
Description of Agency Walk Through
This is a two-story facility and is well maintained and clean. The facility is in
excellent condition and well-furnished in all aspects. There is a significant amount
of frozen, fresh, and dry foods available for the youth and the menu is posted for
the youth to view. All plumbing is in working order and all cleaning supplies are
locked as required. Medication is also locked, and the facility is conducting
emergency drills as required. The bed check logs are also in compliance. All
required postings are in place and the youth’s files are stored appropriately.
4

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. It is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
